posts.title: A Selection of Non-Fiction Booktalks
posts.text: If you love to read non-fiction, perhaps one of these booktalks will grab your attention.

posts.title: Booktalking "Rikers High" and "Surviving the Angel of Death"
posts.text: Read more about two notable tales of survival: the first, a novel from a former Rikers Island teacher; the second, a memoir of incredible survival from one of the most important voices from the Holocaust.

posts.title: Booktalking "After Zero," "Watch Us Rise," and "Like Vanessa"
posts.text: It's all about girl power in these recommended titles, from the world of high school activism to the stages of beauty pageants.

posts.title: Booktalking "One Speck of Truth," "Sophomore Year is Greek To Me," and "Black and White"
posts.text: This edition's YA recommendations take us from Portugal to Greece to the basketball courts of Queens.

posts.title: Booktalking "Out of Place," "Protected," and "The Short Seller"
posts.text: The deleterious effects of bullying, and the ability to rise above it, surface in two featured books, including the latest release from author Jennifer Blecher.

posts.title: Booktalking "Your Score" by Anthony Davenport
posts.text: How is your credit score determined? What are the best ways to improve your score - and why is it so important in the first place? Get Anthony Davenport's "insider secrets" in this book.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Killer Across the Table" by John Douglas
posts.text: As the second season of "Mindhunter" begins on Netflix, we look at the latest book by the man who inspired the series, groundbreaking FBI psychological profiler, John Douglas.

posts.title: Booktalking "96 Words For Love," "Love and Gelato" and "Nikki On the Line"
posts.text: Three novels. Three high-school-age girls, each seeking answers: one in India, one in Italy, and one on the basketball court.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Memory of Light," "Interlude," and "Focused"
posts.text: Discover three tales of teens battling difficult conditions, both physical and emotional, including the latest book from Alyson Gerber, author of "Braced".

posts.title: Booktalking "Braced," "Switching Gears," and "Lies We Tell Ourselves"
posts.text: From physical restrictions to racial divides, discover three novels about various challenges facing young women in high school.

posts.title: Notes from BookExpo America 2019
posts.text: From a live podcast to author panels and awards, BookExpo America is the place to be for any and all bibliophiles. Get an inside look at this year's event, which was held in New York City in late May.

posts.title: Booktalking "Your Destination Is On the Left," "Gemini" and "Royal Crush"
posts.text: This edition's recommendations include a novel about conjoined twin teens and a Meg Cabot book based on her popular "The Princess Diaries".

posts.title: Booktalking "P.S. I Miss You," "Finding Yvonne," and "Shout"
posts.text: With two fiction books - one about teen pregnancy, the other about a high schooler's change in passions - and a lauded nonfiction memoir, here are three titles sure to get your attention.

posts.title: Booktalking "Understanding Your Gifted Child From the Inside Out" and "Zero Waste"
posts.text: What are the best ways to inspire and encourage an intellectually gifted young person? How about reducing your garbage, improving the environment, and living more simply? We have two recommended books that answer those questions.

posts.title: Booktalking "Written In the Stars," "Eden's Escape," and "Good Enough"
posts.text: An arranged marriage, a young genie's adventures, and a look at eating disorders make up this edition's three recommended novels.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Callback," "Step Up To the Plate, Maria Singh," and "The Secret Ingredient"
posts.text: In this edition, we have a selection of books that highlight the passions of three young women - dance, softball, and cooking - including a novel by "Dance Mom" Maddie Ziegler.

posts.title: Teen Author Festival 2019 Recap
posts.text: In the 11th edition of the NYC Teen Author Festival, writers look back at where they were a decade ago, share their creative process, and talk about the current state of YA literature.

posts.title: Booktalking "You Go First," "Front Desk," and "Checked"
posts.text: A 10-year-old girl running a motel front desk? Yep. Meet her and two other dedicated, curious kid characters, in this edition's three recommended books.

posts.title: Booktalking "What Customers Crave" and "Crafting the Customer Experience for People Not Like You"
posts.text: If you're curious about best practices in customer service, these two recommended books provide some timely, excellent advice.

posts.title: Booktalking "Someday," "The Lines We Cross," and "The Lost and the Found"
posts.text: Read about: the third installment of a wildly popular trilogy, a tale about bigoted culture in Australia, and the story of a young woman dealing with the trauma of her kidnapped sister returning to family life.

posts.title: Booktalking "Blended," "Amal Unbound," and "The Pants Project"
posts.text: The challenges and bravery of mixed-race and transgender kids highlight this week's selections of recommended novels.

posts.title: Booktalking "Save Me a Seat," "Amina's Voice," and "Running Through Sprinklers"
posts.text: Indian, Pakistani, and Korean kids all experience challenges in these recommended novels.

posts.title: Booktalking "Anything But Okay," "Soof," and "Army Brats"
posts.text: Managing social interactions at school can be quite challenging, as illustrated by this week's selection of titles.

posts.title: Booktalking "And She Was" and "What You Left Behind" by Jessica Verdi
posts.text: Two teenagers experience serious family challenges while trying to find their way to adulthood, in two books from author Jessica Verdi.

posts.title: Booktalking "Fortune Falls," "Elephant Secret," and "Cyclone"
posts.text: This edition's titles include a story about the haves and have-nots, an elephant refuge, and a family dealing with the stresses of a stroke.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Art of the Swap," "Maxi's Secrets," and "The Angel Tree"
posts.text: In this edition of Booktalking, two girls move across time in an old mansion, and guide dogs play a role in two heartwarming stories.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dangerous Women" and "Survive Like a Spy"
posts.text: Ever wonder what the daily life of a forensic psychologist is like? Check out the first entry in this Booktalking...

posts.title: Libraries in Direct Action: ACRL/NY Symposium 2018
posts.text: This year's Association of College and Research Libraries symposium included frank conversation about racial diversity, reclassification of library materials, and more. See our experience of the day, and mark your calendar for the 2019 symposium!

posts.title: Booktalking "Love and Loyalty," "Evie Brooks is Marooned in Manhattan" and "Soldier Doll"
posts.text: Young adult readers who love animals will appreciate this week's entry: Two recommendations focus on kids' relationships with furry friends, while a third follows the travels of a very special doll.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dear Isaac Newton," "Roll," and "Rescue"
posts.text: This week's Booktalking features a fantastic debut novel about a young pigeon trainer, and the story of a horse-loving seventh-grader who meets a staunch animal rights activist.

posts.title: Booktalking "One Cut," "Different Days," and "Whistling in the Dark"
posts.text: This week's reviews include a tale of two teenagers facing jail time after a childhood of abuse, and two different views of World War II from young people.

posts.title: Booktalking "Counting by 7s," "In a Perfect World," and "Lucky Broken Girl"
posts.text: Read about three top selections that touch on tragedy, change, coming-of-age, and cultural acceptance.

posts.title: Booktalking "The New York Botanical Garden" by Gregory Long and Todd Forrest
Booktalking "The Power of Negative Thinking" and "I Got This"
posts.text: Get inside the minds of two superior members of the sports world - basketball coach Bob Knight and Olympic gymnast Laurie Hernandez - in this pair of autobiographies.

posts.title: Booktalking "Charmed, I'm Sure" and "In Case You Missed It" by Sarah Darer Littman
posts.text: Discover these two fun, personal dramas from author Sarah Darer Littman.

posts.title: Booktalking "Windfall" and "The Foreseeable Future"
posts.text: High-school seniors look beyond a friend's wealth and a family's wishes, in this pair of recommended novels.

posts.title: Booktalking "Blackbird Fly" and "Love Double Dutch"
posts.text: Take a look at two novels about school-age girls trying to make their way in new or challenging situations.

posts.title: Teen Author Festival 2018
posts.text: Celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Teen Author Festival with this recap of the interviews and panels from this year's TAF.

posts.title: Booktalking: "Girl In a Bad Place" by Kaitlin Ward
posts.text: A girl attempts to keep her closest friend from falling prey to the charismatic leader of a cult commune, in the latest edition of Booktalking.

posts.title: Booktalking: "You'll Miss Me When I'm Gone" by Rachel Solomon
posts.text: Jewish twin sisters navigate their respective aspirations while dealing with the possibility of Huntington's disease, in this latest edition of Booktalking.

posts.title: Booktalking: "I Am a Secret Service Agent" by Dan Emmett
posts.text: Dan Emmett fulfilled a life's ambition protecting three U.S. presidents. This edition of Booktalking discusses Emmett's autobiographical look at the Secret Service, and his role within it.

posts.title: Booktalking "Sharpen Your Heels" by Mrs. Moneypenny
posts.text: Maverick Financial Times columnist Mrs. Moneypenny has plenty to say about being a woman in the workplace. But her advice can be helpful far beyond the professional world.

posts.title: Booktalking: "Backfield Boys" by John Feinstein
posts.text: Two New York City football standouts are recruited to play at a Virginia boarding school with a spotty racial history, in John Feinstein's mystery, a current recommendation.

posts.title: Booktalking "Truth or Dare" by Barbara Dee
posts.text: Lia is decidedly lagging behind in the puberty department, longing and praying for the day when all teenage angst will cease.

posts.title: Booktalking: "Arrows" by Melissa Gorzelanczyk
posts.text: What happens when Cupid hits just one person in a couple? Melissa Gorzelancyk's 2016 teen novel puts the Cupid tale in modern-day Wisconsin.

posts.title: Booktalking: "What Momma Left Me" by Renee Watson
posts.text: This 2010 book is another brilliant work from Watson, an inside look at the ugly world of domestic violence and the people left in its wake.

posts.title: Booktalking: "The Names They Gave Us" by Emery Lord
posts.text: Lucy Hansson thinks she's going to have a great summer with her best friend and her boyfriend, Lukas. Then, her plans begins to fall apart.

posts.title: Booktalking: "This Side of Home" by Renee Watson
posts.text: Find out about another stellar novel from Renee Watson about gentrification, racism, and the drama of being a teenage girl.

posts.title: Booktalking "Piecing Me Together" by Renee Watson
posts.text: Jade is a junior at St. Francis High School, and she rides the bus across town to attend the ritzy private school. She is one of a handful of students of color and feels out of place in the mostly wealthy, white, privileged student body.

posts.title: Booktalking "Survivors Club" by Michael Bornstein
posts.text: A series of fortunate events in the hellacious circumstances of World War II led to a little boy's survival.

posts.title: ACRL/NY 2017 Annual Symposium: The Mission
posts.text: Learn about the Greater New York Metropolitan Area's Association of College and Research Libraries annual symposium.

posts.title: Booktalking "Anatomy of Innocence" by Laura Caldwell and Leslie S. Klinger
posts.text: Exculpatory DNA evidence, false witness identification, and law enforcement and legal misconduct lead to an alarming number of innocent people being put into prison for decades.

posts.title: Booktalking "Up To This Pointe" by Jennifer Longo
posts.text: Antarctica is a huge jump from Harper's prior days in California.

posts.title: Booktalking "Cyberbullying and the Wild, Wild Web" by J A Hitchcock
posts.text: Anything posted online can follow people for decades, and kids need to be made aware of the potential consequences of their actions.

posts.title: Booktalking "Witchtown" by Cory Oakes
posts.text: Macie and her mother, Aubra O'Sullivan, lead a nomadic lifestyle scamming community after community. Macie is praying that Witchtown will be their last scam.

posts.title: Booktalking "Halfway Normal" by Barbara Dee
posts.text: Norah begins seventh grade after two years of fighting cancer. Above all, she wants people to forget that she was sick.

posts.title: Booktalking "Wishbones" by Virginia MacGregor
posts.text: When Feather finds her mother collapsed in a diabetic coma on New Year's eve, she knows that she has to do something...and fast.

posts.title: Indie Author Day at the Bronx Library Center
posts.text: We were lucky to host the second annual Indie Author Day. Four authors were featured: Annette Berkovits, Rebecca Brooks, Carmen D. Lucca, and Anne Born.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Fall" by James Preller
posts.text: Sam and Morgan have an "impossible friendship," whatever that is...

posts.title: Booktalking "Charisma" by Jeanne Ryan
posts.text: Imagine that you could become instantly vivacious and popular. Unfortunately, perfection comes with a price.

posts.title: Booktalking "Tim Gunn: The Natty Professor"
posts.text: Tim Gunn has much to say about education, life, and much more—including personal finance!

posts.title: Booktalking "Textrovert" by Lindsey Summers
posts.text: Keeley is a senior high school girl focused on friends and college. Zach and JT are football rivals—two stars vying for limited scholarships. The last thing Keeley wants is to get caught in the cross hairs...

posts.title: "How to Handle a Financial Windfall" at SIBL on August 8, 2017
posts.text: Winning the lottery is what everyone dreams of, right? It can be, but personal safety and security concerns and the anxiety of a significant life change can beset anyone who comes into sudden money.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Dissociative Identity Disorder Sourcebook" by Deborah Haddock
posts.text: The Three Faces of Eve. Sybil. Hollywood portrayals of multiple personality disorder have sensationalized the problem and many mental health professionals—as well as members of the general public—doubt its very existence. Nowadays, this disorder of memory, identity, and consciousness is called Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID), and it is listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) .

posts.title: Booktalking "Star-Crossed" by Barbara Dee
posts.text: Gemma is the apple of Mathilda's eye. Yet, she is shocked when one of her buddies opines that Mattie has a crush on Gemma. What could this mean?!?!

posts.title: Booktalking "The Flip Side" by Shawn Johnson
posts.text: Two names, two lives. Two sides of the same personality. Then the two worlds collide.

posts.title: Booktalking "Great Is the Truth" by Amos Kamil
posts.text: The Horace Mann School. Right in my backyard, in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Supposedly, it was an elite prep school for the future leaders of this country. But behind the brick walls and hallowed classrooms of learning lay a dark truth.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Secret Language of Sisters" by Luanne Rice
posts.text: Mathilda and Ruth, aka Tilly and Roo. Two sisters, so excited to be in the same school again once Tilly entered ninth grade. Then a dog runs in front of Roo's vehicle as she is traveling to pick up Tilly. The ensuing crash devastates her life.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Survival Guide for Parents of Gifted Kids" by Sally Walker
posts.text: Learning how to effectively parent and advocate for a gifted child not easy, but it can be highly rewarding.

posts.title: Summer Reading Kickoff 2017 at Harlem Library
posts.text: As usual, we had a fantastic Summer Reading kickoff celebration this year. We celebrated the beginning of warm weather with a focus on literacy and kids maintaining their reading skills during the upcoming summer vacation.

posts.title: Booktalking "Parenting Gifted Kids" by James Delisle
posts.text: Being gifted means that you lead a charmed life and everything is easier for you, right? Not necessarily.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Power of Noticing" by Max Bazerman
posts.text: We can all become so focused on a particular task that we ignore helpful and relevant information. This is why it is so helpful to take a step back from what you are doing and see if there is a different tactic that could be applied to the situation.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Sacred Lies of Minnow Bly" by Stephanie Oakes
posts.text: This was a fascinating and morbid glimpse into the brutal world of religious cults. The author's alternation of past and present gives the book a dreamy, surreal feel.

posts.title: Booktalking "Everything, Everything" by Nicola Yoon
posts.text: All Madeleine has ever known is life inside of her house with her nurse, Carla and her mother. Until Olly moved next door, that is.

posts.title: Bronx Book Fair 2017
posts.text: I attended the Bronx Book Fair and heard from editors, authors, agents, and library administrators about the world of books, publishing, and accessing materials.

posts.title: Financial Planning Day at SIBL: Spring 2017
posts.text: This was my second visit to the semi-annual Financial Planning Day at the Science, Industry and Business Library. This is a terrific event where I always learn much about finances and money.

posts.title: Booktalking "Faceless" by Alyssa Sheinmel
posts.text: As if losing half of her face to electrical burns is not enough, 16-year-old Maisie must get used to having a stranger's nose, cheeks and chin hanging off of her countenance.

posts.title: Booktalking "Bringing Down the House" by Ben Mezrich
posts.text: No one, except the highest trained security, would ever suspect they could be making off with a cool million.

posts.title: Booktalking "When You Work For a Bully" by Susan Futterman
posts.text: Ever heard of a constructive discharge? That's when an employer makes an employee's work experience so miserable that any reasonable person would leave under the circumstances. But, good news: there are strategies that one can use to fight back.

posts.title: Women in Comics Con 2017
posts.text: I was happy to attend the third annual Women in Comics Con at the Bronx Library Center. I only had time to attend one of the panels, but it included scintillating conversation about women and femininity in comics.

posts.title: TeenLIVE: Gene Luen Yang on Comics and Reading Without Walls
posts.text: Gene Luen Yang is the current National Ambassador for Young People's Literature. We were lucky enough to have him join us for a conversation about comics and his Reading Without Walls challenge.

posts.title: NYC Teen Author Festival 2017
posts.text: I love attending the annual NYC Teen Author Festival, and, as usual, this year's program did not disappoint.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Weight of Zero" by Karen Fortunati
posts.text: Catherine, Cat, Cath... whatever you call her, she is terrified of Zero... Zero breathing down her neck...Zero and approaching D Day...Zero threatening to end everything.

posts.title: Author Talk: "Before the Fires" by Mark Naison and Bob Gumbs
posts.text: On February 18, 2016, the Bronx Library Center invited Bob Gumbs to discuss his book about Bronx history.

posts.title: Booktalking " All We Have Left" by Wendy Mills
posts.text: All We Have Left is a fictive contemplation on 9/11 and its effect on a family 15 years later.

posts.title: Booktalking "Killing It!" by Sheryl O'Loughlin
posts.text: The author gives a unique, more personal look at the world of starting and running a business. She does a fantastic job of addressing the topic in a personable way.

posts.title: Booktalking "Courageous Women Rebels" by Joy Crysdale
posts.text: The stories of these women and more fill the pages of this book: stories of strong women who fought for what they believed in, despite the prevailing views of the day.

posts.title: METRO Conference 2017 In Retrospect
posts.text: On January 11, 2017, I was happy to attend the annual METRO conference for librarian professionals.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Bronx" by Lloyd Ultan
posts.text: The Bronx: the Ultimate Guide to New York City's Beautiful Borough unearths the gems of the Bronx.

posts.title: Booktalking "Careers in Focus: Politics"
posts.text: This book provides a fascinating look at all of the professions that are associated with politics and policy creation in local, state, and federal governments.

posts.title: Booktalking "George" by Alex Gino
posts.text: George loves acting, but she feels a need to hide a part of herself that she fears people will not accept.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Spender's Guide To Debt-Free Living" by Anna Jones
posts.text: In this book, Jones advocates re-thinking how we spend money in order to be more in control of our finances and be happier and more well-adjusted.

posts.title: Booktalking "Elena Kagan: A Biography" by Meg Greene
posts.text: Elena Kagan was nominated to the Supreme Court by President Obama in 2010. Since then, she has written opinions that are known for their clarity. At present, she is one of three female Supreme Court justices.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Mayor's Life" by David Dinkins
posts.text: A Mayor's Life: Governing New York's Gorgeous Mosaic portrays the life of David Dinkins, New York's first African-American mayor.

posts.title: Booktalking "Ten Days a Madwoman" by Deborah Noyes
posts.text: Think women are only capable of writing about fashion and other "feminine" pursuits? Think again.

posts.title: Booktalking "Success Is the Only Option" by John Calipari
posts.text: This is a brilliant book about bringing out the best in extremely gifted people.

posts.title: Booktalking "Symptoms of Being Human" by Jeff Garvin
posts.text: Both and neither. Boy or girl. Coming to terms. Riley struggles to make it in this world, forging a new life and a new way.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Bridge To Brilliance" by Nadia Lopez
posts.text: The Bridge To Brilliance is an eye-opening look into the world of public schools in New York City, especially the economically disadvantaged ones.

posts.title: Timely Talks: Librarians Discuss Money & Power at Regional Symposium
posts.text: The ACRL/NY 2016 Symposium focused on discussions of money and power among librarians. It was a terrific learning experience to collaborate with many colleagues in the NYC area, most of whom work in academic institutions.

posts.title: Booktalking "Women In Blue" by Cheryl Mullenbach
posts.text: This is a terrific history of women in the workplace, as seen through a law enforcement lens.

posts.title: Booktalking "Just Kids From the Bronx" by Arlene Alda
posts.text: The lives of influential people, illustrated in Just Kids From the Bronx, were nurtured in the northernmost borough of the largest city in the United States.

posts.title: Booktalking "Beyond Machiavelli: Policy Analysis Comes of Age" by Beryl Radin
posts.text: The field of policy analysis was born in the 1970s, though the tradition of advising rulers has been around pretty much since the beginning of civilization, as the title suggests.

posts.title: Booktalking "Be a Changemaker" by Laurie Ann Thompson
posts.text: tart changing the world by becoming a social entrepreneur. All you need is passion, drive, time, and commitment to your cause.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Behavior Gap" by Carl Richards
posts.text: Exploring the intersection of using money as a tool for goods and services and happiness.

posts.title: Booktalking "Every Vote Matters" by Tom and Natalie Jacobs
posts.text: Think one voice doesn't matter? Think again.

posts.title: Booktalking "One Perfect Pitch" by Marie Perruchet
posts.text: Ever want to knock someone off his or her feet with your brilliant idea? Trying to get a job, woo investors, or simply persuade someone about a venture that you have in mind?

posts.title: Booktalking "Riding Chance" by Christine Kendall
posts.text: Foster and Troy are best buds, and they hang together always. Then, someone has the idea that they would like to work with horses in exchange for the chance to ride.

posts.title: Booktalking "50 Ways to Protect Your Identity and Credit" by Steve Weisman
posts.text: Common-sense steps that individuals can take to avoid becoming victims of identity theft.

posts.title: Booktalking "Inexcusable" by Chris Lynch
posts.text: According to Keir, Gigi misunderstood what happened, did not speak up, or both, and everything was fine.

posts.title: Booktalking "Girl Online" by Zoe Sugg
posts.text: Penny shares her thoughts in her blog under the alias Girl Online. Anytime something momentous happens in her life, she chronicles the events in public to her fans.

posts.title: Booktalking "Being Jazz" by Jazz Jennings
posts.text: Ever since she was little, Jazz knew she was a girl, despite being designated male at birth.

posts.title: Booktalking "Your Evil Twin" by Bob Sullivan
posts.text: Identity theft proliferates and is rarely ever prosecuted. Learn how to keep your information out of the wrong hands.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Mentor Myth" by Debby Carreau
posts.text: Mentors can assist you with charting your career path, but you must remain at the helm of your life and career.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dangerous Instincts" by Mary Ellen O'Toole
posts.text: Individuals with antisocial personality disorder lack empathy for others, and they are concerned solely with their own desires and needs.

posts.title: Nice Companies Finish First by Peter Shankman
posts.text: Being nice may actually help companies get ahead: happy customers are good for business.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Fractured Mind" by Robert Oxnam
posts.text: This is the true story of someone with Dissociative Identity Disorder.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Running Dream" by Wendelin Van Draanen
posts.text: Jessica dreams of running, and the track team of raising enough money for her prosthetic leg.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Art of Being Normal" by Lisa Williamson
posts.text: Two kids learning about themselves and how they fit in the world.

posts.title: Summer Reading Kickoff 2016 at Edenwald
posts.text: The kickoff event in the Bronx featured singing, dancing, and of course—reading.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Half Life of Molly Pierce" by Katrina Leno
posts.text: A fascinating and realistic portrayal of Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID).

posts.title: Booktalking The Prison Book Club by Ann Walmsley
posts.text: A woman's discoveries while volunteering in a prison book club.

posts.title: Booktalking "If I Was Your Girl" by Meredith Russo
posts.text: Andrew Hardy awakens in a hospital bed in the aftermath of his suicide attempt. If being a boy caused him to want to die, perhaps there is a different reality in store for him.

posts.title: SIBL's April 2016 Financial Planning Day in Retrospect
posts.text: Recap of the classes offered on job hunting, Social Security, asset allocation, and wills at the last event.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Road to You" by Alecia Whitaker
posts.text: Bird Barrett is the latest country music sensation. She lives and breathes words mingled with acoustics.

posts.title: Booktalking "How To Make Your Money Last" by Jane Bryant Quinn
posts.text: Transitioning towards retirement can be a surprisingly difficult process. It can be inspiring and exhilarating to imagine all of the possibilities that life offers to you, but it can be strange and disconcerting to take on a new life and new activities.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Seven-Day Weekend" by Ricardo Semler
posts.text: Semco is a Brazilian company that breaks all of the rules.

posts.title: Booktalking "Look Both Ways in the Barrio Blanco" by Judith Robbins Rose
posts.text: The race to survive and save her mama dominates Jacinta's young life.

posts.title: Booktalking "Backlash" by Sarah Darer Littman
posts.text: Next door neighbors Bree and Lara used to be BFFs... until about a year ago.

posts.title: Booktalking "Gold Medal Summer" by Donna Freitas
posts.text: Joey Jordan is in love with gymnastics. The sport is her hope, her soul and her life.

posts.title: Booktalking "Leadership BS" by Jeffrey Pfeffer
posts.text: Managing emotional expression may be the key to social mobility and attaining higher-paying careers. Leaders are not always modest because they must display confidence.

posts.title: Booktalking "Every You, Every Me" by David Levithan
posts.text: Evan cannot escape Ariel's memory: the way she smiled, the moments that they shared together, what she meant to him. Could he have done more?

posts.title: Teen Author Festival 2016: Authors in Conversation
posts.text: Teen Author Festival NYC is a week-long event that occurs in March of every year. It was great to see so many authors together engaged in a discussion about their craft.

posts.title: Booktalking "My Story, My Dance" by Lesa Cline-Ransome
posts.text: The boy loved karate, but he saw other people prancing through the air, and he informed his mother that he wanted to try another art form.

posts.title: Booktalking "Making Jack Falcone" by Joaquin "Jack" Garcia
posts.text: If you want a safer job, go work in a library. These are the sentiments of undercover FBI agent, Joaquin "Jack" Garcia.

posts.title: Booktalking "City Street Beat" by Nancy Viau
posts.text: Everything is happening in the city. Move with the flow. Kids can play jump rope, skip cracks on the sidewalk, ride on the train or in a carriage around Central Park.

posts.title: Booktalking "Zoe Letting Go" by Nora Price
posts.text: Zoe cannot understand why her mother is signing her off to the staff at Twin Birch. Spending her summer as a patient in a psychiatric treatment facility is definitely not her idea of a good time.

posts.title: Booktalking "Law & Disorder" by John E. Douglas
posts.text: Douglas pioneered the psychological profiling unit of the FBI, known as the Behavioral Research and Instruction Unit.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Word Collector" by Sonja Wimmer
posts.text: Words fed Luna's soul like food nourishes bodies. Life was wonderful when she played with her letters.

posts.title: Booktalking "Can You See Me Now?" by Estela Bernal
posts.text: Amanda writes letters to her dead father. She tells him about her dreams and aspirations. She informs him of her challenges.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Michael Arndt on February 6, 2016
posts.text: Michael Arndt is a graphic designer and also the author of Cat Says Meow. He gave a Power Point presentation about how people process information and how it relates to children's picture books.

posts.title: Booktalking "Destination Unknown" by Amy Clipston
posts.text: Whitney Richards bristles at the ostentatious atmosphere that accompanies wealth and the glamour of high society.

posts.title: "The Year of the Rat" by Clare Furniss
posts.text: Pearl had a good life until childbirth unexpectedly stole her mother from her.

posts.title: Booktalking "Come, Llamas" by Jennifer Morris
posts.text: Kinnaman Ranch in Alaska is home to many llamas, bears and JT.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Dog Trainer's Complete Guide to a Happy, Well-Behaved Pet" by Jolanta Benal
Booktalking "It's Not Just Who You Know" by Tommy Spaulding
posts.text: Tommy Spaulding presents a new take on networking. He calls it netgiving, which is ultimately a more fulfilling and useful way to approach collaborating with colleagues.

posts.title: Booktalking "And We Stay" by Jenny Hubbard
posts.text: Emily Beam is obsessed with the poet, Emily Dickinson. Beam loves to write poetry, and the words for them dance through her head.

posts.title: The Smart Cookies' Guide to Making More Dough
posts.text: Andrea, Angela, Katie, Robyn and Sandra were inspired by an Oprah Winfrey show on personal finance to not only take a look at their desperate financial straits, but to do something about it. They found each other, formed a money group, and they helped each other learn about financial foibles and develop better financial habits.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Alice in Wonderland on December 13, 2015
posts.text: A panel discussion about how Alice has influenced librarians, teachers, authors and illustrators in their crafts.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Secret Side of Empty" by Maria Andreu
posts.text: Monserrat Thalia's gaze on life is losing focus. An undocumented immigrant from Argentina, she is a senior in high school. She cannot see a way into college, considering her status.

posts.title: ACRL/NY Conference on December 4, 2015
posts.text: A recap of the recent Association of College and Research Libraries, Greater New York Metropolitan Area Chapter Conference.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Heart-Led Leader" by Tommy Spaulding
posts.text: Tommy Spaulding has a simple message: caring for employees not only creates a more beneficial work environment, but it drives superior sales and products, as well.

posts.title: Booktalking "Creating Magic" by Lee Cockerell
posts.text: Lee Cockerell has some interesting anecdotes and bits of advice for business leaders, straight from Disney HQ.

posts.title: Booktalking "Becoming Maria" by Sonia Manzano
posts.text: The real life story of one of the stars of Sesame Street.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Latino Literature on October 31, 2015
posts.text: I was excited to learn about Latino literature for youth on October 31 at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building. We had some very interesting panelists, including Daniel Jose Older, Adam Silvera, Sonia Manzano, Torrey Maldonado, and Crystal Velasquez.

posts.title: Take Career Cruising Out For a Spin
posts.text: Learn more about a database that is the next best thing to a career counselor, and free with your library card.

posts.title: Booktalking "After" by Francine Prose
posts.text: Following a shooting at a neighboring school, things begin to change at Central High.

posts.title: Booktalking "Another Day" by David Levithan
posts.text: A inhabits a different body every day of his/her life. A gets the opportunity to experience vastly different people's lives and to forever alter them for better or worse.

posts.title: Booktalking "Why Kids Kill" by Peter Langman
posts.text: The book covers the psychological causes of school shootings and offers unprecedented insight into why certain teens exhibit the potential to kill. The author shows how to identify early signs of possible violence and offers preventative measures that parents and educators can take to protect their communities.

posts.title: Booktalking "Belles" by Jen Calonita
posts.text: Things are a bit different in Emerald Cove than they were in Izzie's home town.

posts.title: Booktalking "Skelly, the Skeleton Girl" by Jimmy Pickering
posts.text: Skelly lives in a haunted mansion, where she makes a surprising discovery…a bone! Who does it belong to?

posts.title: Booktalking "Silent Alarm" by Jennifer Banash
posts.text: Luke had been moody and subject to spells of depression, but no one expected this.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Grand Old Tree" by Mary Newell DePalma
posts.text: There once was a large tree that had deep roots that planted herself sturdily in the ground.  She was a helpful part of the forest.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Very Best Pumpkin" by Mark Kimball Moulton
posts.text: Pumpkin Hollow Farm is where Peter lives with his grandparents and parents. Life is delicious on the farm, and the boy enjoys corn, strawberries, and pumpkins when they are in season.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Smart Girl's Guide: Money" by Nancy Holyoke
posts.text: Tips for young girls on saving and managing money.

posts.title: Booktalking "No Such Person" by Caroline Cooney
posts.text: Lander is the type of person that everyone walks on egg shells around. Including her sister, Miranda.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Profiler: My Life Hunting Serial Killers and Psychopaths" by Pat Brown
posts.text: Profilers provide information about possible suspects; law enforcement solves cases.

posts.title: Booktalking "I'm No Monster" by Stefanie Marsh and Bojan Pancevski
posts.text: The 1980s in Austria was a very patriarchal time and place, and it seems that everyone and their brothers were building underground bunkers to retreat to in case of nuclear attack. This was the the tenor of that country when Elisabeth ("Sissi") disappeared in 1984.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Good, the Bad and the Beagle" by Catherine Lloyd Burns
posts.text: Cadbury, the lemon beagle at the Paws and Claws Pet Store, beckons to Veronica Morgan.

posts.title: Booktalking "Caught in the Web" by Julian Sher
posts.text: Many talented and dogged police officers are on a mission to curtail the horrible abuse of children and to rescue them from further abuse.

posts.title: Booktalking "Lilacs in the Rain" by James Peinkofer
posts.text: A baby nurse in the 1950s was a serial killer.

posts.title: Booktalking "Death Dealer" by Kate Clarke Flora
posts.text: Maria Tanasichuk was loved by her sister, Sharon, her dear friend, Darlene, and her son, B. J., until his tragic death. Then, Maria went on a mysterious trip, and she was never seen again.

posts.title: Booktalking "Stella by Starlight" by Sharon Draper
posts.text: Stella, her brother, Jojo, and her parents struggle to survive in the segregated southern United States in the 1920s.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Killer's Cousin" by Nancy Werlin
posts.text: David's parents send him to live with his cousin, Lily, in an attempt to escape the contempt that the community casts down upon him.

posts.title: Booktalking "Finding Me: A Decade of Darkness" by Michelle Knight
posts.text: Michelle Knight was abducted in 2002 and lived hidden in her captor's house for a decade. The journals she kept chronicle her love for her son and the abuses she suffered.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Lost Girls" by John Glatt
posts.text: Families plastered Cleveland with posters of their missing daughters. The three women were kept hidden for over a decade.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dogtag Summer" by Elizabeth Partridge
posts.text: Her Vietnamese name sounds like the call of shorebirds, but they call her Tracy in America.

posts.title: Superhero Songs From Presley and Melody
posts.text: Presley and Melody have been performing at the library for years, and they always come up with new exciting shows and songs. This year, they made a show to coincide with the superhero summer reading theme.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Summer I Found You" by Jolene Perry
posts.text: Dating your best friend's cousin is a murky business that Kate is not sure that she wants to venture into.

posts.title: Booktalking "Seven Days of Rage" by Paul LaRosa and Maria Cramer
posts.text: The preppy-looking, 6'3", 23-year-old medical student was also a killer on Craigslist.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Worst Princess" by Anna Kemp and Sara Ogilvie
posts.text: Princess Sue has done all of the right things. She grew her braids long. She waited patiently and looked hopefully out the tower window for her prince.

posts.title: Booktalking "Pino and the Signora's Pasta" by Janet Pedersen
posts.text: All of the feral cats of Rome eagerly anticipate the delicious pasta that is regularly brought by the Signora.

posts.title: Networking To Your Next Job with Lisa Hennig
posts.text: Helpful information for job searching, as well as networking within your career in order to perform your job better.

posts.title: Booktalking "White Lines" by Jennifer Banash
posts.text: Seventeen-year-old Cat exists in a netherworld between the banalities of high school and the night club life.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Courage To Take Command" by Jill Morgenthaler
posts.text: Jill Morgenthaler is a retired military colonel who was able to climb up the career ladder and has many words of wisdom for both female and male leaders.

posts.title: Booktalking "Halfway Heaven" by Melanie Thernstrom
posts.text: Sinedu, from Ethiopia, and Trang, from Vietnam, came to the prestigious promised land of Harvard University.

posts.title: Booktalking "Outcasts United" by Warren St. John
posts.text: The Fugees, short for refugees, is a soccer team that revolutionized immigrants' lives in Clarkston, Georgia. Boys from Iraq, Afghanistan, African countries and other nations played soccer barefoot on a field near some apartment complexes.

posts.title: Booktalking "Arms Full of Love" by Delilah
posts.text: Delilah is full of love, and she wants to share it with the world.

posts.title: Booktalking "Rethinking Normal" by Katie Rain Hill
posts.text: Katie Rain Hill was born as Luke. However, she never felt like a boy.

posts.title: Booktalking "Angel Face" by Barbie Nadeau
posts.text: Amanda from Seattle and Meredith from Britain met while studying abroad in Italy. They roomed together with two Italian women. At first, everything was peachy keen, but, as happens so often with roommates, the relationship soon soured.

posts.title: Booktalking "Good Leaders Ask Great Questions" by John Maxwell
posts.text: Business leaders need to retain their curiosity, ask themselves questions to keep at the top of their game, and ask questions of others to determine if they need assistance and to double-check if the leaders need to improve. Questions spur learning.

posts.title: Booktalking "Audition and Subtraction" by Amy Fellner Dominy
posts.text: Tay-Lo. That's how Tatus and Lori's friends have referred to them for the longest time. They always seem to be together.

posts.title: Foundation Grants to Individuals Online Database
posts.text: The Foundation Center provides many databases and books in order to help individuals get grants for their education, work or business.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Matter of Heart" by Amy Fellner
posts.text: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy, HCM, or a heart murmur: Whatever you call it, it could mean the death of Abby Lipman's competitive swim career.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Five Levels of Leadership" by John Maxwell
posts.text: This work presents a positive view of people and their potential. Effective leaders should not simply search for work performance problems to correct. They help staff to develop their skills and achieve their goals.

posts.title: Booktalking "Wild Hearts" by Jessica Burkhart
posts.text: Brie's father is building a hotel while Logan's dad rails against the project because it will displace wild mustangs.

posts.title: Booktalking "Stronger Than You Know" by Jolene Perry
posts.text: Fifteen-year-old Joy is trying to transcend her troubled past.

posts.title: ACRL/NY Mentoring and New Librarian Discussion Group, June 2015
posts.text: ACRL/NY has a mentoring and new librarians meeting twice a year. It is a great chance to meet other new librarians, more experienced librarians and network.

posts.title: Booktalking "Leadership Gold" by John Maxwell
posts.text: Leaders need to examine themselves in order to determine their strengths and weaknesses.

posts.title: Booktalking "Miracle" by Elizabeth Scott
posts.text: Megan is the lone survivor of the Flight 619 crash. Memories of the disaster and aftermath are conspicuously absent when she awakes in the hospital.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Negotiator" by Ben Lopez
posts.text: A first-hand account of a fascinating and high stakes career. A Security companies, such as the one that employs Ben Lopez, work on negotiating ransom sums with the kidnappers and keeping everyone safe.

posts.title: Booktalking "#Girlboss" by Sophia Amoruso
posts.text: Sophia remembers her favorite pair of jeans at age six, and all of the clothing phases that she passed through. She never envisioned herself as the CEO of a multi-million dollar company, but that is exactly what she became.

posts.title: Booktalking "Wanderville" by Wendy McClure
posts.text: Driving a wagon with runaway horses, freedom from child labor, pining for parents to take care of them, and letting their imaginations run wild. The kids in this story have a bunch of fun…on their own.

posts.title: Learning Express Library: Practice Exams
posts.text: Learning Express Library is a great resource to utilize to practice for any upcoming tests that one might have.

posts.title: Booktalking "Guitar Notes" by Mary Amato
posts.text: Lyla and Tripp share a guitar room, but only one person is allowed in the room at a time. Two would be a scandal. So, Lyla uses the room on even days and is "Ms. Even;" Tripp is known as "Mr. Odd."

posts.title: Booktalking "Gluten-Free Birthday for Me!" by Sue Fliess
Booktalking "Red Thread Sisters" by Carol Antoinette Peacock
posts.text: A Chinese legend decrees that a red thread connects those who are destined to meet, and it never breaks. A red thread connects Wen and Shu Ling, as close as sisters in their Chinese orphanage.

posts.title: Booktalking "Not in the Script" by Amy Finnegan
posts.text: Emma Taylor is rich and famous... the dream of any teen, right?

posts.title: Booktalking "Zebra Forest" by Adina Rishe Gewirtz
posts.text: Eleven-year-old Annie, 9-year-old "Rew" (Andrew) and Gran reside together in a country house adjacent to the Zebra Forest. That is, white birch trees interspersed with darkness makes the trees reminiscent of a zebra's stripes. Annie and Rew love the Zebra. They also adore acting out Treasure Island and enjoying other books.

posts.title: Summer Reading Kickoff 2015: Superheroes!
posts.text: I was excited to attend the system-wide summer reading kickoff on June 4, 2015 at the Mott Haven Library. Many staff members, parents and kids, NYPL president Tony Marx, City Council Member Andy King, graphic novelist Nathan Hale and the Mott Haven library staff turned out for this event.

posts.title: Booktalking "Millions of Cats" by Wanda Ga'g
posts.text: An old man and a woman live in a beautiful house in the countryside, but they are lonely without any other people or animals about. Enter cats. Millions of cats.

posts.title: BookExpo America 2015 Recap
posts.text: I was excited to attend my fourth BookExpo this May. The exhibits, as always, were fantastic.

posts.title: Booktalking "Priceless" by Robert Wittman
posts.text: Wittman's first assignment landed him in Philadelphia, a mecca of art. He loves art, so fighting art theft and crime was second nature to him.

posts.title: Booktalking "The League" by Thatcher Heldring
posts.text: Wyatt wants to play football. His father wants him to enjoy golf, as he and his daughter, Kate, do. Brother Aaron extols the virtues of football with Wyatt. Their mother does not want the injuries that come with tackle football.

posts.title: Booktalking "Life is But a Dream" by Brian James
posts.text: Sabrina hears and sees things that are invisible to other people. These experiences are what drives her parents to admit her to the euphemistically named "Wellness Center." There, nurses fill her body up with pills, and the psychiatrists fill her mind with advice and talk, talk, talk.

posts.title: Booktalking "Sugar Hill" by Carole Boston Weatherford
posts.text: Sugar Hill is at the heart of Harlem, New York, the mecca of African American art and culture.

posts.title: Booktalking "My Dad Thinks He's Funny" by Katrina Germein
posts.text: The lame jokes, the corny repertoire. None of it is funny, yet you are supposed to laugh. We've all been there with our parents.

posts.title: Booktalking "PushGirl" by Chelsie Hill
posts.text: Kara Moore was a dancer: The dance studio was home to her, and she even had a Dance Mom to complete the picture. Then, Kara gets hit by a drunk driver on her way to Taco Bell.

posts.title: Booktalking "News for Dogs" by Lois Duncan
posts.text: Andi and Bruce love their dogs, Bebe, Friday, and Red Rover more than anything.

posts.title: Booktalking "Doctor White" by Jane Goodall
posts.text: Hospitals can be scary places for kids. All of the machines, strange noises and people that they do not know can be confusing. Sometimes, they endure painful procedures. They do not feel well, and they do not know what is going on. They miss their friends and family. Luckily for them, they have Dr. White.

posts.title: Booktalking "All Four Stars" by Tara Dairman
posts.text: Gladys Gatsby is a sixth-grade chef-in-training. A bona fide foodie, she loves everything pertaining to food.

posts.title: Booktalking "Return to Sender" by Julia Alvarez
posts.text: 12-year-old Tyler is enjoying life at his Vermont farm, and all seems well. Then, his family hires illegal immigrant Mexican workers.

posts.title: Booktalking "Flying Changes" by Sara Gruen
posts.text: Annemarie Zimmer loves her 17-year-old one-eyed warm blood, Hurrah, and her teenage daughter, Eva.

posts.title: Booktalking "Hider Seeker, Secret Keeper" by Elizabeth Kiem
posts.text: Lana Dukovskaya is a ballerina in the Bolshoi company. She is thrilled to get a chance to go to NYC and dance in The Rite of Spring... but only because star soloist Nina is unwell. And there is speculation as to what caused her injury.

posts.title: Morningstar Investment Research Center
posts.text: Learn how to access Morningstar through the library and the kind of information you can find to support your financial decisions.

posts.title: Booktalking "Librarian on the Roof" by M. G. King
posts.text: This is a story about the oldest library in Texas, the Dr. Eugene Clark Library. This library is over a century old, and it was suffering from disuse due to its old, outdated books. Then, RoseAleta Laurell changed all of that.

posts.title: Booktalking "Do You Know Dewey?" by Brian Cleary
posts.text: Melvin Dewey loved to read, and he made up a system to classify nonfiction books in 1876 that is still used in public and school libraries today.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Birthday Ball" by Lois Lowry
posts.text: Princess Patricia Priscilla and yellow cat, Delicious, lead a life of luxury... but it's boring, boring, boring.

posts.title: Booktalking "I Lived on Butterfly Hill" by Marjorie Agosin
posts.text: Ten-year-old Celeste is living an idyllic life in Chile with her parents, relatives, and friends Gloria, Lucilia, Marisol and Cristobal... until things start changing.

posts.title: Booktalking "Roller Derby Rivals" by Sue Macy
posts.text: In New York City in 1948, Midge "Toughie" Brasuhn and Gerry Murray duke it out on the roller rink for the benefit of thousands of TV viewers.

posts.title: Booktalking "Endangered" by Eliot Schrefer
posts.text: Sophie's in the Congo for the summer, where she helps the bonobos at her mom's sanctuary. Bonobos are an endangered species, and mothers get killed in the wild so that the locals can sell the babies as pets. That is how Sophie meets Otto.

posts.title: Booktalking "Vincent's Colors" by Vincent Van Gogh
posts.text: yellow sky and sun / blue and white jug / grey-green trees and pink sky / yellow buttercups...

posts.title: Booktalking "Black Gold" by Marguerite Henry
posts.text: U-see-it is small, but what she lacks in size, she makes up for in heart.

posts.title: Booktalking "Stable" by Ted Lewin
posts.text: The barn on Caton Place was built in 1930. They provide riding lessons, pony rides, parties, and carriages for special events. Gallop, a therapeutic riding program, helps people with disabilities improve their lives through contact with equines.

posts.title: Booktalking "Molly the Pony" by Pam Kaster
posts.text: A children's book telling the story of a pony with a prosthetic leg.

posts.title: Booktalking "Blue Ribbon Summer" by Catherine Hapka
posts.text: Brooke is in love with her Chincoteague pony, Foxy. She schools the pony herself, but it is a slow, gradual process.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Lost and Found Pony" by Tracy Dockray
posts.text: The pony in this story is plaintive and adorable.

posts.title: Booktalking "Born to Trot" by Marguerite Henry
posts.text: Rosalind is a mare that Gibson can hang his hopes on. The young boy loves exercising horses, and he loves the way that the trotting Standardbred moves. She is all heart, and she responds to her driver's urging with all that she has.

posts.title: Children's Book Week is May 4-10, 2015!
posts.text: At a recent Children's Literary Salon, Children's Book Council Communications Director, Nicole Deming, gave a presentation about the history and present day of Children's Book Week.

posts.title: Book TV: Author Interviews and More
posts.text: Book TV features interviews with authors, which may be followed by audience questions, information about book fairs and other book-related events across the nation, panel discussions that feature authors discussing literary themes, and interviews with curators and mobile book librarians.

posts.title: Booktalking "Goal!" by Mina Javaherbin
posts.text: Ajani and friends play football in South Africa... after he has finished his homework and gotten water from the well.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Summer of May" by Cecilia Galante
posts.text: May and Olive text each other all day long. May's fiery temperament is calmed by Olive's gentle ways; they seem to complement each other... until they stop understanding each other.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Judaism
posts.text: The event was hosted by Betsy Bird, Youth Materials Specialist, and it featured Marjorie Ingall from Tablet Magazine, Joanna Sussman from Kar-Ben Publishing, and Barbara Krasner from the Sydney Taylor Book Award Committee.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dear Wandering Wildebeest" by Irene Latham
posts.text: African animals grace the pages of this thoughtfully illustrated book.

posts.title: Booktalking "Carmen Learns English" by Judy Cox
posts.text: Carmen teaches her little sister Lupita English, and she teaches the kids at school Español, solamente un poquito.

posts.title: Booktalking "Animal Stars" by Robin Ganzert
posts.text: Everyone on the crew falls in love with canine and feline film actors. The human actors, fans and crew alike love walking around holding cuddly animals.

posts.title: Booktalking "Otto the Book Bear" by Katie Cleminson
posts.text: Otto is a book bear. He loves books, and he also lives inside one.

posts.title: Booktalking "Miss Dorothy and Her Bookmobile" by Gloria Houston
posts.text: Dorothy missed librarianship, but then the people had a town meeting in which it was brought up that they used to have a rolling library.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Incredible Book Eating Boy" by Oliver Jeffers
posts.text: Henry has a voracious appetite for books, and he cannot stop consuming them. One day, he gets bored, so he sneaks a taste of a single page, which leads to a chapter, and eventually an entire book.

posts.title: Mango Languages: Travel the World
posts.text: Want to learn a new language? Do you know that we have a service that provides visual and auditory instruction for 64 different languages?

posts.title: Kentucky Horse Park: Museums and More
Booktalking "Get Real" by Mara Rockliff
posts.text: Cheap stuff wreaks havoc on the environment.

posts.title: Booktalking "Smart Boys" by Barbara Kerr
posts.text: However, gifted males can face social isolation from their peers due to their intellectual differences. They often feel pressured to choose between excellence and normality.

posts.title: NYC Teen Author Festival, March 2015
posts.text: This two-day event is a terrific forum for allowing new authors to present about their work. Many authors, teachers, librarians and teens attend this event.

posts.title: Booktalking "5 Levels of Gifted" by Deborah Ruf
posts.text: Gifted kids are characterized by intensity, creativity, precocity, perfectionism, and idealism.

posts.title: Booktalking "Genius Denied" by Jan and Bob Davidson
posts.text: Gifted kids are often bored in academic classes with their age-mates, and they do not share similar interests. Therefore, they can feel lonely and get depressed or angry if their educational and socio-emotional needs are not met. Luckily, there are some solutions.

posts.title: Booktalking "Why Smart People Hurt" by Eric Maisel
posts.text: Natural psychology is a 21st Century invention whose basic tenet is that a sense of meaning and purpose in life provides gratification and well-being. The author discusses one billion, or 15% of the 7 billion people who currently populate earth, as being intellectually bright. Certain challenges face these individuals.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Accuracy in Illustration on March 7, 2015
posts.text: Authors Mara Rockliff, Brian Floca, Sophie Blackall and editor Nicole Raymond sat down with Youth Materials Specialist Betsy Bird to discuss the idiosyncrasies of kid lit pictures. But first, they each gave a presentation about illustration and their books.

posts.title: Booktalking "Daisy to the Rescue" by Jeff Campbell
posts.text: The stories go on and on about animals that go out of their way to rescue sick and injured people. This book is inspirational.

posts.title: Booktalking "Rotten" by Michael Northrop
posts.text: Jimmer Dobbs (JD) returns home at the end of the summer only to discover that his mother has acquired a new housemate, a rescued Rottweiler.

posts.title: Booktalking "Buddy" by M. H. Herlong
posts.text: Twelve-year-old Lil'T, aka Tyrone, meets his best friend, a dog whom he christens Buddy, on his way home from church one day.

posts.title: Using Academic Search Premier for College Research
posts.text: Learn how this database can help you with your studies—log in from home with your library card!

posts.title: Booktalking "Numbering All the Bones" by Ann Rinaldi
posts.text: Eulinda is a 13-year-old girl searching for freedom during the Civil War. That didn't happen for her younger brother Zeke, who was recently sold to another master.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Break With Charity" by Ann Rinaldi
posts.text: The witch trials are a circus. The afflicted girls, as well as many local residents, attend the trials. The accused witches are not appointed counsel, and their words of defense fall on impatient ears.

posts.title: Booktalking "Finishing Becca" by Ann Rinaldi
posts.text: The Declaration of Independence was penned in 1776. This is Philadelphia in 1778, in the midst of the Rebels and the Loyalists. 14-year-old Becca Syng is sent to work and live as a maid with the spoiled Peggy Shippen, future wife of Benedict Arnold.

posts.title: Booktalking "Reviving Ophelia" by Mary Pipher
posts.text: In her practice, the author found adolescent girls falling victim to cultural ideals of thinness and feminine behavior.

posts.title: Booktalking "Mable Riley" by Marthe Jocelyn
posts.text: It is 1901 in America, and 14-year-old Mable has different ideas than her more conservative schoolteacher sister Viola.

posts.title: Booktalking "Girl in Blue" by Ann Rinaldi
posts.text: Sarah Wheelock, a.k.a. soldier Neddy Compton in the Civil War, is a 16-year-old runaway who also becomes a spy for the Union.

posts.title: Booktalking "Behind the Gates of Gomorrah" by Stephen Seager
posts.text: Napa State Hospital houses some of the most dangerous criminals in the nation... with no guards. Why? Hospitals do not have guards. Most of the patients have either been found "not guilty by reason of insanity" or "incompetent to stand trial."

posts.title: Booktalking "The Case for Loving: The Fight for Interracial Marriage" by Selina Alko
posts.text: Richard Loving and Mildred Jeter were living a fulfilled and happy life in Virginia. They wanted to turn their relationship into the committed partnership of marriage, but in 1958 in Virginia, interracial marriage was illegal.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Collaborating Couples on February 7, 2015
posts.text: Andrea and Brian Pinkney, Sean Qualls and Selina Alko, and Betsy and Ted Lewin spoke about living and working on books together.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Patron Saint of Butterflies" by Cecilia Galante
posts.text: The Regulation Room is simply a normal part of life on Mount Blessing to its residents.

posts.title: METRO Conference on January 15, 2015
posts.text: Highlights from the local library conference.

posts.title: Booktalking "Breaking the Ice" by Gail Nall
posts.text: Kaitlin's luck seems to be failing her. Telling the judges at a competition exactly what she thinks of her low scores for artistic expression leads to her demise at the Ridgeline Skating Club.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Letter Writer" by Ann Rinaldi
posts.text: Eleven-year-old Harriet Whitehead is hired to write letters for a blind woman on a Virginia cotton plantation in 1830. There, she meets 14-year-old Violet, a half-black and half-white girl who becomes her soul sister.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Ever-After Bird" by Ann Rinaldi
posts.text: The scarlet ibis is known to the slaves as the Ever-After bird. Legend has it that once a slave sights this bird, he or she will be free.

posts.title: Booktalking "Willow" by Tonya Hegamin
posts.text: Willow gets into trouble for reading anything other than the Bible... and she is also not supposed to know how to write. So she hides her diary in the woods.

posts.title: Booktalking "Justice While Black" by Robbin Shipp and Nick Chiles
posts.text: A criminal defense attorney with a quarter-century experience gives advice to young men of color in order to avoid and minimize harm done if they get arrested. However, it is useful for all citizens to know about and exercise their rights.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Lions of Little Rock" by Kristin Levine
posts.text: It is 1958 in Little Rock, Arkansas, and the debate about racial integration in schools is raging.

posts.title: Booktalking "My Thirteenth Winter" by Samantha Abeel
posts.text: Dyscalculia is a math-related learning disability. Samantha Abeel was caught in the crossfire between her complete inability to perform simple mathematical calculations or read music (which is related to math) and her extreme creativity with writing and vivid imagination.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Science Fiction on January 3, 2015
posts.text: Authors and librarians weighed in on the subject of sci-fi in children's books at the event earlier this month.

posts.title: Booktalking "Trapped" by Michael Northrop
posts.text: No heat, no water, no cell phone reception... and no help on the way.

posts.title: Booktalking "Sugar White Snow and Evergreens" by Felicia Chernesky
posts.text: The illustrations in this book are exquisite, and I love how Swan emphasizes single colors in the double-page spreads.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Publishing in the 21st Century on December 6
posts.text: Betsy Bird, Youth Materials Specialist at NYPL, introduced the program. Jane Breskin Zalben moderated the panel, which consisted of Laurent Linn, Leonard Marcus, Neal Porter, Caroline Ward, Susan Roth, and Elizabeth Harding.

posts.title: Association of College and Research Libraries, New York Chapter
posts.text: The ACRL/NY chapter puts on an annual symposium and has a mentoring program as well.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dear Santa, Please Come to the 19th Floor" by Yin
posts.text: Carlos is wheelchair-bound due to an accident that damaged his spinal cord. He is depressed due to the injury and the dramatic change in lifestyle, but luckily his best friend lives in the building.

posts.title: Metropolitan New York Library Council: Training for Librarians
posts.text: One of the many advantages of large urban areas is increased opportunities for professional development. METRO is one of the most helpful librarian professional organizations that I have found in New York City.

posts.title: Booktalking "Tease" by Amanda Maciel
posts.text: Sara is being charged with the harassment and assault of Emma Putnam. Emma is dead.

posts.title: Booktalking "Code Talker" by Joseph Bruchac
posts.text: Sixteen-year-old Ned Begay is used to being called stupid and other names by adults. So  joining the Marines and going through boot camp is not especially challenging for him.

posts.title: Booktalking "Twenty-One Elephants and Still Standing" by April Jones Prince
posts.text: The Brooklyn Bridge took fourteen years to build, and the people in Manhattan and Brooklyn all eagerly awaited its completion.

posts.title: Booktalking "I Have Two Homes" by Marian De Smet
posts.text: Sometimes she lives with Mom, sometimes with Dad... in two different houses.

posts.title: Booktalking "Prisoner B-3087" by Alan Gratz
posts.text: B for Brikenau Concentration Camp, 3087 for prisoner number. This is how the Nazis define Yanek.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Brooklyn Nine" by Alan Gratz
posts.text: A novel told in nine stories, spanning the years from 1845 to 2002.

posts.title: Booktalking "Can You Ever Forgive Me?" by Lee Israel
posts.text: This book tells the story of how one author fell on hard times and decided to try her hand at selling valuable correspondence from prominent authors.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Other Side" by Jacqueline Woodson
posts.text: Clover notices a little girl on the other side of the fence. She wants to play with her and her friends, but everyone's mothers told them not to go over the fence.

posts.title: Booktalking "Eagle Song" by Joseph Bruchac
posts.text: Danny does not fit in New York City with his long hair and Mohawk ways.

posts.title: Booktalking "Lumber Camp Library" by Natalie Kinsey-Warnock
posts.text: Amazingly enough, these lumberjacks who topple logs every day are a little bit afraid of literature.

posts.title: Booktalking "Paper Daughter" by Jeanette Ingold
posts.text: Maggie Chen, 16-year-old summer intern at the Herald newspaper, follows in her journalist father's footsteps. She gets caught up in the fascinating flurry of activity in the newsroom, investigating a suspicious death with one of the reporters, which seems to be connected with her own father's demise.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Sundown Rule" by Wendy Townsend
posts.text: Louise's mother is out of the picture, and her dad is on a writing assignment for National Geographic in Brazil. She finds herself staying with Aunt Kay and Uncle Jack for the summer.

posts.title: Booktalking "Lizard Love" by Wendy Townsend
posts.text: Grace loves reptiles. She paints snakes, Nile monitors and chameleons on her jacket. Walter at Fang and Claw, a reptile pet store, is jealous; he wishes that he had a jacket like hers.

posts.title: Booktalking "Second Impact" by David Klass
posts.text: Football is the lifeblood of this small Jersey town, and the administration does not react kindly to negative publicity about its prized sport.

posts.title: Booktalking "Click, Clack, Moo: Cows That Type" by Doreen Cronin
posts.text: These cows have an issue with their living conditions. So they decide to do something about it. They start communicating their suggestions to the farmer.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Native Fiction on October 4, 2014
posts.text: Stacy Whiteman and Cheryl  Klein are editors, and Joseph Bruchac and Eric Gansworth are Native authors. It was interesting to see the interchange between authors and editors during the program.

posts.title: Booktalking "This is How I Find Her" by Sara Polsky
posts.text: Sixteen-year-old Sophie has essentially been her mother's caregiver for the last five years. Not by her choice. However, Sophie loves the capriciousness carefree nature of her mom, her lovely paintings, and her terrific sense of fun. The mother she can be when not crippled by bipolar disorder.

posts.title: Booktalking "Wild Things!" by Betsy Bird, Julie Danielson and Peter Sieruta
posts.text: Want to know more about the authors of children's literature, where they came from, and why they write the books that they do? This book will provide some elucidation, as well as a brief chronology of the evolution of kid lit.

posts.title: Booktalking "Prisoner 88" by Leah Pileggi
posts.text: Imagine being stuck in a dark, dank cell overnight with men twice or thrice your age, or more. At least 10-year-old Jake had his own cell in the Idaho Territorial Penitentiary.

posts.title: Booktalking "Halloween Hustle" by Charlotte Gunnufson
posts.text: There is a terrific dance out there that you may not know about—the Halloween hustle. Moving and grooving to the beat of the Halloween treat.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Boys of the Dark" by Robin Gaby Fisher
posts.text: The Florida School for Boys, which was renamed the Arthur G. Dozier School for Boys sometime after the 1960s, is a juvenile detention facility for underage male offenders. Michael O'McCarthy and Robert Straley were inmates in the 1950s and 1960s.

posts.title: Booktalking "Catch Me If You Can" by Frank Abagnale, Jr.
posts.text: Frank William Abagnale, Frank Williams, or any of the other aliases he gave people, cruised through life alternately as an airplane pilot, pediatrician, civil lawyer, academic professor, and finally as a researcher/writer in what he thought was the safe haven of Montpellier, France. He bought a nice cottage there, and he brought a suitcase full of cash with him.

posts.title: Booktalking "Confessions of a Master Jewel Thief" by Bill Mason
posts.text: I have always been fascinated by thieves who could pull off multimillion-dollar heists, steal paintings from museums beefed up with security, etc. However, all of the stories included a ring of thieves. Not this one.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Marc Aronson on September 6, 2014
posts.text: Marc Aronson led a discussion at the library about nonfiction for kids.

posts.title: Booktalking "Tasting the Universe" by Maureen Seaberg
posts.text: The phenomenon of experiencing associated senses (a kind of cross-wiring) is an old concept, but it has only been scientifically studied since the second half of the 20th Century.

posts.title: Booktalking "Ultraviolet" by R. J. Anderson
posts.text: Alison Jeffries wakes up at St. Luke's Hospital, her mind foggy from psychotropic meds. From there, it's to Pine Hills, or "Fine Pills," as fellow patients have christened the psychiatric hospital.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Girl Who Heard Colors" by Marie Harris
posts.text: Jillian is a sensory maven. She loves all her senses: taste, smell, touch, vision and hearing.

posts.title: Booktalking "Looking Out For Sarah" by Glenna Lang
posts.text: Perry tells the world what it is like to be Sarah's seeing-eye dog.

posts.title: Booktalking "Mirror, Mirror on the Wall" by Barry Denenberg
posts.text: At the Perkins School for the Blind, Bess becomes close with her roommates shy Eva and flamboyant Amanda. They amuse themselves with talk about their evil housemother, Mrs. Burton.

posts.title: Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library: An Insider Look
posts.text: This library provides services for blind customers in all five boroughs of New York City and Long Island.

posts.title: Booktalking "Twisted" by Laurie Halse Anderson
posts.text: Seventeen-year-old Tyler Miller has a probation officer now. Apparently, this makes him a lot cooler at school. At least beautiful Bethany Milbury seems to think so.

posts.title: Booktalking "Somebody Up There Hates You" by Hollis Seamon
posts.text: They've got spirit; they're not depressed. 17-year-old Richie and 15-year-old Sylvie think that they are in love; they have terminal cancer, and they live in hospice care. Every minute they can find, Richie and Sylvie spend together.

posts.title: Booktalking "A Death-Struck Year" by Makiia Lucier
posts.text: Cleo Berry is a 17-year-old schoolgirl in Oregon in 1918 when her school closes due to the Spanish influenza epidemic. In order to stave off boredom, she signs up to volunteer with the Red Cross.

posts.title: Booktalking "Wind Dancer" by Chris Platt
posts.text: Seventh-grader Allison has decided that she is finished with horses. Her best friend Cara has an adorable pony called Dumpling, and she invites Ali to ride her mother's horse any time. Allison declines. The girls become concerned about two Appaloosas on a neighboring farm that are emaciated.

posts.title: Booktalking "Dear Blue Sky" by Mary Sullivan
posts.text: Sef is at the center of Cassie's family. Everyone adores Sef; he seems to keep the family together, and Cassie loves her early morning runs with him. The world crumbles when he decides to fight in the Iraq War.

posts.title: Booktalking "Everything You Want" by Barbara Shoup
posts.text: Emma never imagined that her psychology class goose, Freud, would be her ticket to the good life. She and her family spend an anxious sleepless night waiting to turn in a winning lotto ticket at the convenience store when it opens at 8 a.m.

posts.title: Booktalking "Catalyst" by Laurie Halse Anderson
posts.text: Kate Malone is a super-charged high school senior, long-distance runner, and she has her heart set on attending MIT. No other college will do. At her school, everyone is defined by their grade point averages and college destinations. Kate, with her brother Toby, minister father, Siamese cat Sophia, and black lab Mr. Spock, take on the world. National Honor Society member and perfectionist, Kate's thoughts run a mile a minute.

posts.title: Booktalking "What We Lost" by Sara Zarr
posts.text: Being raised by a pastor must be a dream come true, right? Not if your alcoholic mother is in rehab. Samara's father seems more present for the parishioners than for his own daughter.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Lucy Variations" by Sara Zarr
posts.text: Sixteen-year-old Lucy Beck-Moreau is a former concert pianist who quit. No more piano for Lucy, not even for fun. This contrasts starkly with her 10-year-old brother Gustav, who now studies with Will and spends many practice hours at the keyboard.

posts.title: Booktalking "How to Save a Life" by Sara Zarr
posts.text: "Do you have a heart that needs a home? I have a home in need of a heart."  Robin posted this query on a random adoption web site in hopes of finding a baby to love. Mandy clicked on it.

posts.title: Booktalking "Life, After" by Sarah Littman
posts.text: Daniella, little sister Sarita, and parents emigrate from Argentina to Twin Lakes, NY in an attempt to start a new life, free from terrorism.

posts.title: Booktalking "Want to Go Private?" by Sarah Littman
posts.text: Fourteen-year-old Abby is starting ninth grade, and nothing is more comforting to her than venting about her daily trials and tribulations to BlueSkyBoi, aka Luke Redmond, on chezteen.com.

posts.title: Children's Literary Salon in Retrospect: Podcasting on April 19, 2014
posts.text: I was happy to have Katie Davis, John Sellers and Matthew Winner as podcasters on the latest Children's Literary Salon panel. This event is hosted by Betsy Bird, Youth Materials Specialist at BookOps. Katie Davis is a children's and teen author as well as the host of the podcast "Brain Burps About Books." John Sellers works for Publisher's Weekly, and he hosts the "PW Kids Cast." Matthew Winner is a school librarian, one of the 2013 Library Journal Movers and Shakers, and he hosts the "Let's Get Busy" podcast.

posts.title: Booktalking "The One Left Behind" by Willo Davis Roberts
posts.text: Mandy was used to doing everything exclusively with her sister; they even dressed alike. She feels as though half of herself, half of her person hood is gone forever. Amanda cannot express her feelings to her family since she thinks that they will not understand. The kids at school do not know what to say to her.

posts.title: Booktalking "Shooter" by Walter Dean Myers
posts.text: Why school shootings? Look through the eyes of Leonard Gray, Cameron Porter and Carla Evan, three teens who were at one, two of whom had weapons, one of whom died.

posts.title: Booktalking "Handbook for Boys: a Novel" by Walter Dean Myers
posts.text: Jimmy Lynch learns about self-efficacy and choosing your own destiny at Duke's place, a barbershop. Duke Wilson even hires Jimmy to help him move a friend as an excuse, Jimmy thinks, just to get an opportunity to talk to the boy some more. Maybe the barber is bored, Jimmy surmises, after his wife died. Needs something to do.

posts.title: Read Everywhere!
posts.text: Read everywhere today and every day. A lot of us love reading already, but why is it important?

posts.title: Booktalking "Pointe" by Brandy Colbert
posts.text: Theo is a high school junior torn between becoming a pro ballerina or finding another job. She and all of her friends are entranced with drug use, and she spends her time at parties and navigating her relationship with pianist Hosea and her childhood friend Donovan.

posts.title: Booktalking "Purge" by Sarah Littman
posts.text: Janie struggles with her problem child status, her "perfect" stepsister Jenny, and her relationship with her best friend Kelsey back home.

posts.title: Booktalking "Duke" by Kirby Larson
posts.text: Hobie Hanson's father is fighting in World War II, and now the Dogs for Defense is looking for any German Shepherds that people can possibly spare for the war effort.

posts.title: Booktalking "A World Away" by Nancy Grossman
posts.text: Sixteen-year-old Eliza is going through rumspringa, an adolescent exploration that occurs in Amish communities.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Library Dragon" by Carmen Agra Deedy
posts.text: Sunrise Elementary School had a dragon lady, literally, as its new librarian. The school had never had a dragon in the library before. She considered it her job to guard the books and protect them from sticky fingers. Every book was in its correct place, and she took the liberty of burning any books that she perceived to have anti-dragon sentiment contained within them.

posts.title: Booktalking "Blink Once" by Cylin Busby
posts.text: West wakes up to discover that he is paralyzed and cannot move his limbs. He discovers a room full of hospital machines, strange sounds, and strange sights. He blinks once for yes and twice for no in order to communicate with the world. West was a biker who fell into a disastrous, incomprehensible world.

posts.title: Anti-Prom 2014: Punk Rock
posts.text: Halfway through the event, students from the High School of Fashion Industries had a fashion show. They modeled their outfits by walking up and down the curved staircases in Astor Hall. Chic and funky punk rock outfits abounded.

posts.title: Booktalking "Gifted Grown Ups" by Marylou Kelly Streznewski
posts.text: Gifted children are considered special education students: smarter than 95% of the population, with an IQ (Intelligence Quotient) of 130 or higher. An IQ of 100 denotes average intelligence. There are also qualitative measures of people's abilities. Howard Gardner conceptualizes people's strengths in terms of multiple intelligences. Gifted adults are also characterized by quick mental speed, sophistication of thought, high levels of sensitivity, drive, and a sense of humor.

posts.title: Booktalking "The Unruly Queen" by E. S. Redmond
Booktalking "Gifted Children" by Ellen Winner
posts.text: According to Winner, gifted children share three characteristics: precocity, insistence on marching to their own drummers and a rage to master.
